Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54394-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
June 2021 
 
 
Mongolia: Enhancing Private Sector Outreach 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

(as of 12 May 2021)

NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide a knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) to expand ADB’s nonsovereign 
operations (NSO) in Mongolia. The TA will focus on (i) increasing the private sector’s awareness 
of ADB’s financial products, investment principles, and eligibility criteria; and (ii) enhancing project 
readiness and implementation.  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and the goals of ADB’s Operational Plan for 
Private Sector Operations, 2019–2024.1 The TA is included in the country operations business 
plan for Mongolia, 2021.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Over the past 3 years, ADB has intensified its NSO efforts and approved four projects in 
Mongolia totaling $62.1 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (as of May 2021).3 Before 
the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, ADB increased the number of missions fielded to 
Mongolia from the resident mission in Beijing and ADB headquarters in Manila to identify and 
negotiate  small-scale  private  sector  projects  in  the  infrastructure,  financial  institutions, 
agribusiness, and social sectors. The government has recognized and appreciated this effort. 
 
4.  The government has highlighted the importance of a more dynamic private sector to 
Mongolia’s future economic prospects. In policy priorities, the government has identified an 
ambitious infrastructure pipeline and recognizes that private sector financing is essential for the 
successful implementation of this pipeline.4 Over the longer term, Mongolia wants to develop 
dynamic, private-sector-led economic sectors in the non-mining space to support continued 
efforts  to  diversify  the  economy.5 The  government  has  underlined  the  catalytic  role  that 
international financial institutions (IFIs) can play to provide finance, build capacity, and give 
increased confidence to prospective investors. Thus, the Ministry of Finance requested ADB to 
further expand its efforts to reach out to private sector companies and to increase its pipeline of 
NSO in the country. 
 
5.  ADB’s nonsovereign engagement adds significant value to private sector financing in 
Mongolia,  and  ADB  coordinates  closely  with  the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development (EBRD) and the World Bank Group’s International Finance Corporation (IFC), the 
two other major actors in private sector operations. ADB’s absence in the traditional mining sector 
allows for a dedicated focus on supporting and developing the non-mining sectors, a unique 
situation among IFIs. ADB is also well placed to use its large sovereign portfolio to complement 
the success and lessons from NSO with upstream efforts to strengthen the investment climate—
an important priority for ADB in Mongolia because of the recent stagnation in Mongolia’s business 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila; 
and ADB. 2019. Operational Plan for Private Sector Operations 2019–2024. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2020.  Country  Operations Business Plan:  Mongolia,  2021. Manila. The  TA was  listed as  Preparing 
Nonsovereign Operations. The title of the TA was revised to better describe its scope. The TA first appeared in the 
business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 January 2021. 
3  The four projects are:) (i) Gender Inclusive Dairy Value Chain Project (2019), (ii) Sermsang Khushig Khundii Solar 
Project (2019), (iii) Senior Loans to XacBank and TenGer Financial Group for Supporting Micro, Small, Medium-
Sized Enterprises and Leasing Finance (2019), and (iv) Tavan Bogd COVID-19 Wheat Supply Chain Liquidity 
Support Project (2020).  
4  State Great Khural. 2020. Government Action Plan, 2020–2024. Ulaanbaatar. 
5  State Great Khural. 2020. Mongolia’s Vision–2050. Ulaanbaatar.

2 
 
climate reforms in recent years.6 This complementarity between NSO and sovereign work and 
the focus on investment climate reform will be a core priority of the upcoming country partnership 
strategy for Mongolia, and the proposed TA will be a key part of this approach.7 ADB is already 
showing leadership among the IFIs in complementing NSO with upstream sovereign work. For 
example, ADB is coordinating a joint position paper on the investment climate in Mongolia with 
EBRD and IFC. This builds on the excellent collaboration between ADB and peer IFIs at the 
transaction level, which will continue to underpin ADB’s approach on NSO.  
 
6.  The success of fully expanding ADB’s NSO financing depends on the depth of ADB’s 
engagement with the country’s private sector, which is a time- and resource-intensive process, 
especially for smaller transactions. Further outreach to the business community will require 
additional human resources to provide the necessary expertise and ignite the momentum for NSO. 
Challenging  economic  and  geographic  conditions  call  for  a  further  boost  of  the  business 
development capacity within the country. With this TA, ADB will recruit experienced business 
development professionals to reach out to private sector companies and state-owned enterprises 
and drive new project pipeline growth in Mongolia on behalf of ADB. The TA will complement 
ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department’s (PSOD) business development efforts, market 
research, transaction support, and portfolio management activities in the country. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: NSO financing and partnerships with various 
sectors in the Mongolian economy supported (Government Action Plan, 2016–2020).8  The TA 
will have the following outcome: readiness and design quality of ADB’s NSO financing improved.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Project identification and preparation capacity of Mongolia’s businesses 
with high development impact strengthened. This output will identify and support commercially 
viable private sector companies to generate a beneficial social or environmental impact and 
improve their capacity to get access to long-term capital in the international financial markets. 
Through workshops and seminars, the TA will support selected private sector companies to 
prepare  and  implement  projects  with  high  development  impact  in  energy,  infrastructure, 
manufacturing, agribusiness, and services. This will also help the private sector better understand 
essential features of projects that ADB will consider for direct financial assistance. Private sector 
participants will be identified based on available market studies and ADB’s assessments. 
 
9.  Output 2: Knowledge of ADB’s nonsovereign operation financing and private sector 
awareness of ADB’s financial instruments, investment principles, and eligibility criteria 
improved. This output will help strengthen the potential private sector clients’ ability to benefit 
from ADB’s NSO financing through outreach workshops. During project implementation, the TA 
will organize at least three events each year: one project promotion workshop, one thematic 
seminar,  and  one  outreach  conference.  The  TA-supported  knowledge  products,  including 
brochures and product notes, will enhance the private sector’s awareness of ADB’s assistance 
 
6 For example, Mongolia has fallen from 59 in the Doing Business Survey in 2014 to 81 in 2020. 
7 This is scheduled for approval in the third quarter of 2021. 
8 Government of Mongolia. 2016. Government Action Plan, 2016–2020. Ulaanbaatar. The project’s design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
 
and available products for NSO. ADB will also explore the preparation of background sectoral 
knowledge products such as diagnostic studies and/or mapping of private sector players. This will 
be explored in coordination with peer IFIs to avoid unnecessary duplication of knowledge products 
and to better coordinate knowledge efforts. The focus of these events and knowledge products 
will be the non-mining sectors. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $525,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-7). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2.  
 
11.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff 
remuneration, domestic transportation, office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB Mongolia Resident Mission and PSOD will co-lead 
administration and will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants; organize workshops; and 
provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshop. 
 
13.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank.

4 
 
14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration  instructions 
and/or staff instructions.9 The TA will engage one international consultant (a total of 12 person-
months) and three national consultants (a total of 72 person-months). Consultants will produce 
the TA outputs and deliverables effectively and in a timely manner, will organize and carry out all 
TA activities, and will report to the ADB project officer. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Enhancing Private Sector Outreach, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board. 
 
 
9  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
Output 1: Project preparation capacity for ADB’s nonsovereign operation financing strengthened 
1.1. Recruit and field consultants by July 2021 
1.2. Conduct an inception workshop with the MOF, business associations, and private sector 
companies by June   2021 
1.3. Submit TA progress report every 6 months (September 2021–June 2023) 
1.4. Screen commercially viable projects and report the results on a daily basis to ADB (MNRM and 
PSOD) 
Output 2: Knowledge of ADB’s nonsovereign operation financing and private sector awareness of 
ADB’s  financial instruments, investment principles, and eligibility criteria improved 
2.1. Recruit and field consultants by July 2021 
2.2. Conduct seminars on ADB products and requirements every 6 months (September 2021–June  
2023) 
2.3. Organize at least three events per year: one project promotion workshop, one thematic seminar, 
and one outreach conference (July 2021–June 2023) 
Inputs 
ADB: $500,000 from Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-7) 
Government of Mongolia: $25,000 
Note: The government will provide counterpart support in form of counterpart staff remuneration, 
domestic transportation, office supplies, and other in-kind contributions. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, A= assumption, COVID-19 = coronavirus disease, MOF = Ministry of Finance, 
NSO = private sector (nonsovereign) operations, TA = technical assistance, MNRM = Mongolia Resident Mission, 
R = risk, OP = operational priority, PSOD = Private Sector Operations Department. 
a Government of Mongolia. 2016. Government Action Plan, 2016–2020. Ulaanbaatar. 
Contribution to Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities: 
The expected values and methodological details for all OP indicators to which this TA will contribute results are 
detailed in the Contribution to Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities (accessible from the list of linked documents 
in Appendix 3). This TA will contribute results for: 
OP 1.2.2  Models for business development and financing established or improved (number) 
OP 2.1.3 Women-owned or -led SME loan accounts opened or women-owned or -led SME end borrowers 
reached (number) 
OP 6.1.2 Measures supported in implementation to improve capacity of public organizations to promote the 
private sector and finance sector (number). 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
